title: U.S. stocks pull back as investors react to higher Treasury yields, deal to avert railway strike
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA was off 53 points, or 0.2%, to 31,079.

* The S&P 500 SPX fell 25 points, or 0.7%, to 3,920.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP declined 113 points , or 1%, to 11,607.

On Wednesday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 30 points, or 0.1%, to 31135, the S&P 500 increased 13 points, or 0.34%, to 3946, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 86 points, or 0.74%, to 11720.

What's driving markets

With stocks still smarting from Tuesday's inflation print, which triggered the worst selloff for U.S. stocks in two years, Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B. Riley Financial, said investors were looking at a number of factors influencing markets, including the narrowly-averted railway strike.

See: White House says tentative pact has been reached to avoid railway strike

The stocks of railroad operators rose as Biden spoke publicly to confirm news of the deal, with Union Pacific UNP Corp. up 2.4%, while Canadian Pacific Railway Limited CP was down 0.2%. The Dow Transportation Average DJT was up 0.1%.

Wall Street had fretted that the railway strike could exacerbate inflation at a time when consumer prices already were rising at a clip of 8.3% year-over-year in August.

Investors were also looking at the economic data deluge and the ongoing inversion of the 2s/10s yield curve, as the 2-year yield traded around 40 basis points above the 10-year yield.

"There are three inputs driving markets today and the largest of them is people being hyper-focused on the yield curve, especially the two year, which remains stubbornly high," Hogan said.

"This is a reflect of our interpretation of what monetary policy will be in the short term."

In U.S. data Thursday retail sales rose 0.3% in August as Americans spent more on new cars and trucks and went out to eat more, suggesting the economy grew at a steady pace toward the end of the summer.

Meanwhile new jobless benefit claims fellby 5,000 to 213,000 in the week ended Sept. 10, the Labor Department said, suggesting the labor market remains healthy.

However, two regional gauges of manufacturing sentimentmoved into slight contraction territory in September, according to data released Thursday.

In recent trade, the 2-year yield BX:TMUBMUSD02Ywas up 7.2 basis points to 3.844%, while the 10-year yield BX:TMUBMUSD10Yis up 3.1 basis points to 3.446%.

As the weekend approaches, market participants are looking ahead to next week's two-day Federal Reserve policy meeting, where the central bank is largely expected to hike its benchmark interest rate by 75 basis points or more.

Fed funds futures traders are pricing in increasing odds of a 100 basis-point hike, which Nomura has said is its base case. Hogan said expectations around next week's meeting could be keeping a lid on stocks as investors are reluctant to open new long positions.

Stocks in focus

* Adobe Inc. ADBE shares were down more than 16% after the software company fell short with its revenue outlook for the current quarter and announced plans for a $20 billion merger deal.

* Shares of Humana Inc. were up more than 7% as the company raised its profit outlook.

* Valero Energy Corp. VLO, Chevron Corp. CVXand Exxon Mobil Corp. XOMwere all trading lower, along with most of the oil and gas stocks on the S&P 500, as oil prices dropped. West Texas Intermediate crude futures WBS.1 tumbled more than 4%, while the Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund XLEwas down more than 2%.

Hear from Carl Icahn at the Best New Ideas in Money Festivalon Sept. 21 and Sept. 22 in New York. The legendary trader will reveal his view on this year's wild market ride.
